Activity: Arrive at the office, settle in, and check emails for any urgent requests or updates. Quickly browse some photography websites for inspiration.
Review the week's goals: identifying historical medical records, developing a data abstraction form, and training data abstractors.
Begin identifying locations of historical medical records. Start with electronic records within our existing EHR system. Make a list of potentially relevant databases and file storage locations.
Email @ITPM-1, @DBA-1 to inquire about access protocols and security requirements for accessing historical EHR data. Topic: EHR Data Access Permissions
Investigate the physical storage locations of paper-based medical records. Locate the archives and record storage rooms. Document the organization system (if any).
Lunch Break. Head out for a quick walk around the block to clear my head.
Continue investigating the physical storage locations. Focus on records pre-dating EHR implementation. Note any challenges (e.g., disorganized files, damaged records).

Start drafting a preliminary list of EHR data elements relevant to influenza trend analysis (patient demographics, vaccination status, diagnosis codes, symptoms, lab results, prescriptions, hospitalizations). Refer to past influenza reports for guidance.
Email @HIS-1, @HIS-2 to get the access permission for the historical influenza reports. Topic: Permission for Influenza Historical Reports
Refine the list of EHR data elements, considering data quality and availability. Prioritize elements that are consistently documented and easily accessible.
Prepare a summary report of the day's activities, outlining progress made in locating medical records and identifying key EHR data elements.
End of day. Listen to some music on the way home.
